positive.review: This is a great Pass time.  I find myself Totally Immersed in this game.  The hours I play naturally depend on how I feel on any particular day.  Lately, having found that i am terminal with cancer, and battling spinal stenosis, it has become  double sided coin.  First it keeps my mind occupied and my hand active to different actions required to make the keyboard function work.  this agame helps me iun so many ays

I've enjoyed hundreds of hours of Giant's FS games over the years and they keep improving, and FS25 is no different. The latest update introduces a gorgeous new map and fishing mechanics but even without that optional DLC the core game is excellent, add on some free maps like Silverrun Forest and there are alot of options for different gameplay styles available

Do you like large projects that require huge amounts of resources to complete, that changes as you contribute to it, and is visually updated - then FS's "contruction projects", an optional feature (that can be ignored if you just want to "farm") add that aspect, and boy it's so much fun

If you enjoy the process of building a "business" from the ground up that is here too - start small (even give yourself some debt to clear from the get go) and build up over in-game years until you own factories, production lines, land and bigger machines as you aim for that "$10,000,000 in the bank" achievement

Want to jump straight to a big farm with everything and just plow the fields? Go ahead, start off with tons of cash and go big off the bat, even add on the optional "Precision Farming" mod for extra realism if that's your thing - or if you like the realism on the lower end there are options to turn it all off, so no weeds, lime, plowing etc. Everyone is catered for

Speaking of mods - well this has plenty, to put it mildly. Are they essential / required? Nope. Do they enhance the game? For sure! Mod support is even part of the main menu, no external software required, and they don't break achievements. There are websites dedicated to them and Giants even supply the software on their website so you can start making your own

What's missing? Hmm, maybe some of the repairing & restoration gameplay in Farmer's Dynasty? But one could argue even that is kinda there with it's construction projects...

Overall it's a very polished high quality game (is "game" the right word?) and I've enjoyed every moment of it - never had any issues with performance, nor has it crashed, nor have I experienced any bugs. If that doesn't qualify as an overall positive experience, I don't know what does

I'd say its the best farming simulator out there. Very realistic, challenging too (expecially for people like me who have no idea of anything about the vehicles or crops) and its beautiful game too.
ALSO! The game is not just about crops, you can also own businesses, take care of animals and do lumber (with vehicles) and aloottt mmoooreee!! Very recommended!

I came to this game from long experience with sandbox games, but no real-life agricultural experience at all.  I'm a city girl who grew up across the street from an automotive plant, and know very little of farming.  I mean, I understood that plants are farmed from the land and that follows seasons, and that herds of animals are kept for meat, wool (sheep), eggs (chickens), and so on.  But other than that... not much, lol. 

For someone like me who has never been involved in the rural, agricultural way of life, it's a STEEP learning curve.

In order to build up some basic background knowledge in the subject, I've resorted to leaving my "legit" playthrough for another future time and just on learning how things work on farms.  I've googled how to activate the console commands/unlimited money to make that a non-issue, and am just taking lots of contracts out and using the "lease equipment" option on them, then resorting to looking things up on the Internet when I get stuck.  I'm learning a ton about the different kinds of equipment and different tasks people do around farms.  

If anyone else loves sandbox games but is being hamstrung by a complete lack of agricultural knowledge, that might help you.  It's helping me, at least.
The game is good and realistic, but it is very complicated and might be hard for some to  understand

The most detailed and realistic farm sim the game community has to offer and on top of that you can play it online with all your friends :)

[b]Originality[/b]
 Giants' studio is one of the first companies to make such a precise game around the farming world as most competitors have basic farming functionality as an addition to the main game but this is where this game is different, instead of farming being a small mini game inside of the main game as a bit of padding to the main story this game is all about farming with a countless amount of machines and ways to play the game. This is the only game that I willingly purchase at release, regardless of their previous game, because unlike EA with their football/soccer games, this game always evolves drastically from its previous release. 

[b]Consistency/Fun[/b] 
I find this game drastically enjoyable and that is granted through the countless ways of playing from doing basic contracts at the start with nothing and building up to a farming empire via the use of the 23 different crops for a game revolving around a field or using greenhouses and being able to grow 10 different plants in a small form factor which will require a tedious amount of forklift usage or if you don‚Äôt like the business management part you can also start out with millions and play this game as you would Minecraft in creative. There are many ways of playing this game, which just makes the game very re-playable and enjoyable in the long term. 

[b]Previous Games[/b]
This is an ongoing series of games set in the farming world; their previous PC, Xbox and PS game was Farming Simulator 22. 

[b]Difficulty[/b]
This game is not the easiest to adjust to; it may require a lot of extensive research on the game‚Äôs mechanics and even research on real-life farming. Ideally, if you have never played a game from this franchise (or farmed in real life), it would be best to play with a friend who has because there are many mechanics that people who haven‚Äôt invested hundreds of thousands of hours into this game won‚Äôt be familiar with, and all this leads to is premature quitting. Gameplay - Farming Simulator 25 has no ending. This is a crucial thing to remember: you must be creative and constantly set goals for yourself, which shouldn‚Äôt be too hard, as there is always a different you can do to increase profits. Replay value - Even though this game never ends, you may want a new start. The best part of this game is the beginning, where you must strategize every single one of your moves, and luckily, starting fresh isn‚Äôt annoying because of the countless crops, production chains, farming methods, and animals you can tend to. 

[b]Modability[/b]
Farming simulator has always and will always have a strong modding community, and even Giants Software makes mods for the community, such as their precise farming mod, which makes the game even harder and even more realistic. Modding is available in the vanilla version of the game on both PC and console, but PC does have a larger array of mods compared to console as they can run more extensive code and download mods from the internet, whereas console is locked to the in-game mod menu which in my option is more than enough already, it always guarantees greater safety for the user. 

[b]Storage Capacity Required[/b]
‚âà 45GB

[b]Graphics[/b]
This game has the best graphics compared to their older games, but if you like hyper-realistic, breath-taking graphics, then the graphics could be better. The attention to detail with environmental factors is extremely impressive as seen with vehicles getting stuck in mud, rain system which isn't only graphical and the ground deformations due to different vehicles and different weight makes the game so much more immersive and enjoyable. The environmental aspects isn‚Äôt surprising given that the whole game's point is sowing and harvesting. 

[b]Stability[/b] 
This game is currently quite stable without any game-breaking bugs that the average user will experience but bugs do pop up here and there even in normal gameplay so be beware and report any bugs to https://feedback.giants-software.com/login_page.php. 

[b]Multiplayer[/b]
The online aspect works flawlessly but the only downside is for the average user who wants to set up a 24 hour home server they will not be able to set up a server on a separate machine such as a raspberry pi as the game for one forces the owner of the server to buy two copies of the game + DLCs - one for the server and the other for themselves as a client - and another issue is that the game doesn‚Äôt offer a stable linux server file meaning they will have to have a strong enough computer to have the game running with graphics and an active session.

[b]Overall[/b]
I love this game and all of their previous games and therefore would definitely recommend this game to anyone interested.

Farming Simulator 25 is the most complete and polished FS experience so far.
I‚Äôve put in dozens of hours and the game keeps getting better as you unlock new machinery, expand fields, and build your farm your way.

Gameplay & Progression

The core loop is extremely satisfying.
Corn silage + BGA, poplar chips, cotton, grass, forestry ‚Äî everything works smoothly and every job feels meaningful. The improvements to crop growth, lighting, and weather add more realism without making the game complicated.

Vehicles & Machines

The machinery lineup is massive, with excellent sounds and animations.
Running machines like the Claas Jaguar, CR11 combine, large sprayers, and wheel loaders feels powerful and immersive. Used vehicle market is fun and often gives amazing deals.

Graphics & Performance

Huge improvement from FS22.
Better lighting, cleaner shadows, more realistic terrain, and generally smoother gameplay.
Runs well even on mid-range laptops like RTX 3050 Ti once you tune settings.

New Features

Better AI workers

Improved field management

More production chains

Smooth BGA and silage workflows

Poplar and forestry feel more rewarding

Crop textures and animations upgraded

What Could Be Better

AI still gets confused in weird-shaped fields

Some performance dips on ultra settings

A few tools and systems need balancing

Mods will make the game even better later

Final Verdict

If you love farming, building, expanding, and managing a big operation with hundreds of machines, FS25 is absolutely worth it.
It‚Äôs addictive, relaxing, and extremely satisfying once your farm takes off.

Farming Simulator 2025 has become one of my most played titles this year, and despite its early shortcomings I still actively enjoy it. At launch the performance issues were hard to ignore, with fps drops and shader stutter occurring frequently. Thankfully the game has improved over time and now runs noticeably smoother.

Graphically the game is undeniably modest. As a simulation focused on repetitive fieldwork, I personally do not see any real value in features like ray tracing. When you are harvesting soybeans for the fourteenth time on the same field, visual effects matter far less than clear visibility and a stable framerate.

Logging remains a mixed experience. Using a mouse makes the controls feel clunky and awkward, but with a joystick or controller the activity becomes surprisingly smooth and enjoyable. If you plan to engage in logging regularly, a controller is almost essential.

One of the most disappointing additions for me was the new extreme weather system. It was heavily advertised but ultimately underdelivers, as storms mostly just damage crops without offering anything visually impressive or mechanically interesting. It feels like wasted potential for a more dynamic challenge.

Worker behavior, however, has improved significantly from previous entries. You can fine tune their settings and they now operate far more logically in fieldwork. Being able to set them to complete the headland first and then finish the inner field makes automated tasks much more reliable and efficient.

Another pleasant addition is the set of large construction projects included in the original maps. These multi stage builds can be completed by delivering the required materials and serve as great long term goals for each savegame. They add a sense of progression beyond simple farming routines and make the world feel more alive.

Content wise the game launched a bit light, but Giants has strengthened it with several high quality official mods available for free on the in game Modhub. These updates make the game feel more complete and show consistent developer support.

The modding community deserves enormous praise. There are countless maps and game changing mods that add both depth and realism. I strongly recommend financial overhaul mods that introduce proper interest rates and annuity loans, as well as mods that rebalance machinery wear to prevent a situation where an old combine becomes scrap metal after harvesting a single small field. These mods elevate the experience and make long term progression far more believable.

Personally I spend a lot of time on the Chadlington map, recognizable from Clarkson‚Äôs Farm. Its tight village layout brings its own challenges and keeps everyday tasks interesting. Like many simulation games, Farming Simulator 2025 is at its best when played with friends or when you simply want to unwind and think about something other than your day job.

Overall Farming Simulator 2025 is a solid and continuously improving entry in the series. With community mods it becomes a deep, flexible and highly enjoyable farming experience that I can easily recommend.
I've been a huge fan of the Farming Simulator series over the years, and this game is the best one yet.
I'm not sure exactly what it is that I like about this game. I guess I just like building things up and accomplishing things. When I recommended it I told them it was relaxing.

Farming Simulator 25 feels like the series settling comfortably into its groove. It looks cleaner, runs smoother, and gives you a big lineup of machines to work with. It doesn‚Äôt try to reinvent anything, but it definitely feels more polished and easier to get into if you‚Äôve enjoyed the older games.

The new Highlands Fishing Expansion is a nice change of pace. You get a fresh map, some new crops, and the whole aquaculture system, which adds something different to focus on besides the standard fieldwork. It‚Äôs not a massive overhaul, but it brings enough variety to keep things feeling new.

Mods are where the game really shines. FS25 is already solid, but with mods it can feel like a totally different experience. The community adds everything: custom maps, new vehicles, realism tweaks, graphical upgrades, production chains, and more. If you‚Äôre willing to explore the mod hub or third-party sites, you can tailor the game to exactly how you want to play.

Overall, Farming Simulator 25 comes across as a comfortable and improved version of the series. The DLC adds some fun extras, and the modding scene keeps the game exciting long after the base content. It‚Äôs not a groundbreaking sequel, but it‚Äôs easily the most flexible and enjoyable entry so far.

Farming Simulator 25 is the only game where I can spend 6 hours harvesting virtual potatoes while my real-life plants are dying on the windowsill. The graphics are so good that I genuinely apologized to a cow after driving a $300,000 tractor straight through her field like a drunk lawnmower.
The gameplay is pure chaos in slow motion. You think, ‚ÄúOh cool, I‚Äôll do a little farming,‚Äù and suddenly it‚Äôs 3 a.m., half your fields are crooked, your tractor is upside down in a ditch, and you‚Äôve somehow leased five machines you can‚Äôt afford.
Multiplayer is even worse. Invite your friends and watch them immediately sprint toward the nearest expensive equipment and flip it. Someone always becomes the ‚Äúaccidental arsonist‚Äù even though the game doesn‚Äôt have fire.
Also, shoutout to the economy system: I sell 10 tons of wheat and make like $12. I sneeze too hard and vehicle repair costs $40,000. Truly realistic.
Animals are great though. Cows stare at you like they‚Äôre judging your life choices. Chickens roam around like they own the property. And horses? Don‚Äôt even get me started. I rode one directly into a fence for 30 seconds and the game praised me for ‚Äútraining.‚Äù
Overall: Farming Simulator 25 turns normal people into sleep-deprived crop addicts. 10/10 would crash my tractor into a barn again.

Based on my 6hrs of gameplay:

Pros:
- Baby animals, yay
- Dynamic animal pens
- Colliders (soil/deposited materials react to weight, if i used that term correctly)
- Cleaner HUD
- Steering Assist (great for one's OCD straight-line urges)

Cons:
- Graphics feel... flat, soft & dark (this is an IMO)
- No male animals. This is a basic necessity for realism.
- NPCs (IMO, creepy as heck. I much rather liked the 2d portraits from FS22 in the contracts panel)

It‚Äôs 2025 and FS25 still runs on a very old engine.
That‚Äôs honestly the biggest problem.

The game has potential, but the graphics feel stuck somewhere between FS15 and FS17. Almost nothing in the world reacts to light properly, the trees don‚Äôt move, the foliage is dead, and the whole map feels static and flat. It‚Äôs not ‚Äústylized,‚Äù it‚Äôs just outdated.

The worst part?
Most of the Steam screenshots look way better than the actual game. They‚Äôre heavily edited, downsampled, captured in a debug mode or simply not representative of normal gameplay. Once you play it yourself, everything looks overexposed, washed out, and with zero atmosphere.

Even with ReShade you can‚Äôt fix the core issues, because the engine doesn‚Äôt support any modern features. No raytracing, no GI, no proper sky lighting, no volumetric shadows, nothing. Other simulators moved forward (UE4, UE5, HDRP, etc.), but FS25 still uses DX11 and old screen-space tricks that break with FOV or camera movement.

The trees are a perfect example:
No proper animation, no believable lighting, no depth, no softness, no scattering. They look almost the same as in FS15. And when the environment looks dead, the whole game feels dead.

FS25 plays fine, but visually it‚Äôs extremely outdated.
If you expect modern graphics in 2025, you will be disappointed.

Don't forget the wood, it's unplayable.

My expectations of Farming Simulator were the relaxing farming/automation experience, something akin to a tranquil Satisfactory or a snug progression-focused farming game. However, as an absolute beginner, I was very confused, if not overwhelmed, pretty much instantly.

The game lets you into a large sandbox where you are able to get acquainted with all the different tools, machines, fertilizers, and agricultural terms that the tutorial does not explain at all. There are different tools that are very similar in appearance, items with the same specifications but different names, and a lot of authentic agricultural terms that are simply not known to the majority of people. The game is not very helpful at all in teaching the player what the various things are that are not real-world farming.

You soon find yourself surrounded by seasons, crop calendars, various soil treatments, weeds, lime, PH, and different tillage tools, and left trying to comprehend the differences between cultivators, plows, mulch, power harrows, direct seeders, subsoilers, sprayers, spreaders, etc. It is not user-friendly, and as a newbie, it seems to be an unnecessarily complicated experience.

Also, there is not any real development, objectives, or a feeling of going in the right direction. If you are the kind of gamer who likes to have a clear path to follow or tech progression, then Farming Simulator would feel very dull to you. It is practically an open-to-air sandbox with no directions or significant goals, which might be fun if you are already acquainted with the whole process, but not if you are a lone learner.

I completely understand the reason for the long-time fans to love the franchise. If you have been playing FS for several years or if you are acquainted with real-life farming machines, then everything seems to be in sync. But for a novice looking for structure, progression, or intuitive systems, the experience is confusing, overwhelming, and not very fun at all.

Still more ‚Äúarcade farm‚Äù than simulator

I‚Äôve played Farming Simulator for years and honestly thought 25 would finally push things closer to a real sim.

Gameplay & physics
The game still feels very arcadey. Vehicles don‚Äôt feel heavy, physics are pretty much nonexistent. For something calling itself a simulator, it really doesn‚Äôt behave like one.

Missing depth
We‚Äôre in 2025 and there are still no proper pesticides, plant diseases, or any real depth to crop management. Fields feel way too clean and simple. No risk, no pressure, nothing to really think about besides the same old loop we‚Äôve already done in previous games.

Bugs
And of course, there are a lot of bugs. AI issues, little glitches, stuff that adds up over time and gets annoying. It doesn‚Äôt feel as polished as a new full price release should.

Graphics
Graphics are slightly better, but better visuals alone are not enough reason to buy what basically feels like the same game again.

Overall
If you‚Äôre hoping for a truly deeper, more realistic farming sim, this isn‚Äôt it. Right now it feels like a slightly prettier version of what we already had, with the same shallow systems and a bunch of new bugs.

If you want to have a good time playing with your friends, stay well clear... this is the same rinse and repeat of previous farming simulators most notably FS22, Giants from what I can see have done nothing to improve the game bar a few extra skins, the same issues with the game engine are there.. sluggish and bad response to input from other players to the host, this is even with a dedicated server (you need to buy an extra licence key for this), I held off for so long hoping they will eventually fix the issues but now I feel a mug for buying it.

I also find it crazy that others cant join your game if you have one of the dlc's that is essentially a skin or even a vehicle, why not let them join your game but stop them from operating the vehicle??? other games have this feature, at least those who are stupid enough to pay for money grabbing dlc's get to enjoy them whilst also trying to enjoy a game with friends, rather than not being able to use it because friends need to waste their money too!

I know and enjoy the fact that there will be some muppets frothing at the mouth wanting to spam my review because I have bad mouthed their beloved game developer (not that they actually develop games anymore), oh well..

If you thinking of getting this to play with friends don't, it will frustrate you a lot, its almost impossible to do precise moves with forklifts or even moving objects by hand due to the slight delay in response.

Playing solo, go for it! just remember to use the mods the community provide, they provide the game with content that will help keep you entertained for hundreds of hours, I would wait for it to be on a big sale, avoid the dlc's apart from the expansion packs you can download the other dlc's on external websites for free and just put them in your mod folder, its all legit, its just stuff the community have made in past years that giants have just rolled in glitter and sold mugs like me.

It‚Äôs 2025 and FS25 still runs on a very old engine.
That‚Äôs honestly the biggest problem.

The game has potential, but the graphics feel stuck somewhere between FS15 and FS17. Almost nothing in the world reacts to light properly, the trees don‚Äôt move, the foliage is dead, and the whole map feels static and flat. It‚Äôs not ‚Äústylized,‚Äù it‚Äôs just outdated.

The worst part?
Most of the Steam screenshots look way better than the actual game. They‚Äôre heavily edited, downsampled, captured in a debug mode or simply not representative of normal gameplay. Once you play it yourself, everything looks overexposed, washed out, and with zero atmosphere.

Even with ReShade you can‚Äôt fix the core issues, because the engine doesn‚Äôt support any modern features. No raytracing, no GI, no proper sky lighting, no volumetric shadows, nothing. Other simulators moved forward (UE4, UE5, HDRP, etc.), but FS25 still uses DX11 and old screen-space tricks that break with FOV or camera movement.

The trees are a perfect example:
No proper animation, no believable lighting, no depth, no softness, no scattering. They look almost the same as in FS15. And when the environment looks dead, the whole game feels dead.

FS25 plays fine, but visually it‚Äôs extremely outdated.
If you expect modern graphics in 2025, you will be disappointed.

Based on my 6hrs of gameplay:

Pros:
- Baby animals, yay
- Dynamic animal pens
- Colliders (soil/deposited materials react to weight, if i used that term correctly)
- Cleaner HUD
- Steering Assist (great for one's OCD straight-line urges)

Cons:
- Graphics feel... flat, soft & dark (this is an IMO)
- No male animals. This is a basic necessity for realism.
- NPCs (IMO, creepy as heck. I much rather liked the 2d portraits from FS22 in the contracts panel)
- UI is obviously different from FS22 that may need getting used to, but there was nothing bad with the previous UI style for the store & placing down buildings.
- No 3rd POV interaction with vehicles and trailers, it is still automatic touch-of-a-button, not a big issue but doesn't score realism points.
- Re-used models, especially for animals (you'd think being a new game, you'd get new models for stuff)

Conclusion:
IMO if the pros from FS25 had been added to FS22, it would've been a near perfect game. I wouldn't pay full price for FS25, especially since modders have gone to lengths to make FS22 more complete with the additions that FS25 included. Seems like a money grab, but whatever floats your boat.
